968 Go back and fix your own shithole instead of running here (www.cbsnews.com) posted 4 days ago by South_Florida_Guy 83 comments award share report block Over 250,000 Venezuelans in U.S., including thousands in South Florida, to lose Temporary Protected Status For the past several years, many Venezuelans have been shielded by TPS, a federal program that allows migrants from unstable countries to live and work legally in the U.S. www.cbsnews.com

Am I expected to care enough to do homework? permalink award report block reply Trajano 3 points 4 days ago The article is correct. Once the status expires, they will have no work authorization and will need to leave. If they stay, they are here illegally and can be deported. If they file for asylum, they will remain legally in the country until their claim is processed and an immigration officer or judge rules on whether to approve or reject their asylum application. The twist  is that processing an asylum application takes U.S immigration a very long time because of Biden's open border policies, which have overflowed the system and created a huge backlog: "The average wait time for cases in front of the Executive Office for Immigration Review (EOIR) is approximately 4.3 years, with some courts, such as the one in Omaha, Nebraska, reporting wait times approaching 6 years.
In some instances, cases may extend beyond 10 years due to the large number of pending cases—over 1 million as of recent data—with an average wait time of more than 1,364 days for those granted asylum in FY 2023." During that time, the applicants will receive a work authorization and a legal status to remain in the country until their asylum claims are resolved. The lawyer in the article speculates that they have a full year to apply (it may be true or not), but until they file the claim,  they are here illegally. Full disclaimer, I am not an immigration lawyer, but someone with more knowledge than I has explained the whole process to me. permalink parent award report block reply Michalusmichalus 2 points 4 days ago Thanks for the details. permalink parent award report block reply stillbringingitback 1 points 4 days ago Venezuelans are, IMO, some of the more deserving refugees. Am I expected to care enough to do homework? permalink award report block reply Trajano 3 points 4 days ago The article is correct. Once the status expires, they will have no work authorization and will need to leave. If they stay, they are here illegally and can be deported. If they file for asylum, they will remain legally in the country until their claim is processed and an immigration officer or judge rules on whether to approve or reject their asylum application. The twist  is that processing an asylum application takes U.S immigration a very long time because of Biden's open border policies, which have overflowed the system and created a huge backlog: "The average wait time for cases in front of the Executive Office for Immigration Review (EOIR) is approximately 4.3 years, with some courts, such as the one in Omaha, Nebraska, reporting wait times approaching 6 years.
In some instances, cases may extend beyond 10 years due to the large number of pending cases—over 1 million as of recent data—with an average wait time of more than 1,364 days for those granted asylum in FY 2023." During that time, the applicants will receive a work authorization and a legal status to remain in the country until their asylum claims are resolved. The lawyer in the article speculates that they have a full year to apply (it may be true or not), but until they file the claim,  they are here illegally. Full disclaimer, I am not an immigration lawyer, but someone with more knowledge than I has explained the whole process to me. permalink parent award report block reply Michalusmichalus 2 points 4 days ago Thanks for the details. permalink parent award report block reply
